## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
summary(cars)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)

read.csv
AcaciaSaligna_Data <- read.csv("AcaciaSaligna.csv")
library(dplyr)
AcaciaSaligna_Data <- dplyr::select(Year, Vegetation_Type, Quadrat, Total_Number,
Total_Density, Seedling_Number, Seedling_Density, Adult_Number, Adult_Density)
AcaciaSaligna_Data <- read.table("AcaciaSaligna_Data.csv", header = TRUE, sep = ",", 
						colClasses = c("NULL","integer", "character", "integer", "integer", "numeric", 
										"integer", "numeric", "integer", "numeric", "NULL")) 

# declaring a character vector 
VegType_vec <- c("Strandveld", "Ecotone", "SandFynbos") 
print("Original String") 
print(VegType_vec) 

# getting the class of vector 
class(VegType_vec) 

VegType_mod <- as.factor(VegType_vec) 
print("Modified String") 
print(VegType_mod) 

# getting the class of vector 
class(VegType_mod)
```
